meeting_annotations.speaker: Elaine Hsiao
meeting_annotations.transcript: especially for the organoids. meeting_annotations.speaker: Elaine Hsiao
meeting_annotations.transcript: Exactly. And Sarkis, to your point, I think you're mentioning going top down is important, starting with the most complex. meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, like, you know, kind of leveraging the advantages of both systems. meeting_annotations.speaker: Sarkis Mazmanian
meeting_annotations.transcript: So, so don't you worry that you're missing a cell type that might dramatically change the effect that you're looking at, let's say the neuron?

meeting_annotations.transcript: It's also important to think about the idea that a metabolite might be critical for a process, but it might not influence all the cells in that process. meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi

meeting_annotations.speaker: Lisa Osborne
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think, I mean, for all of these, it depends on what your question is, right? Every single model that you, that we've talked about has a caveat associated with it. And every single model has a strength associated with it. Whether or not it's communication across tissues or the bulk of the metabolites or the bulk of the community. If you're interested in a single cell type, how does it respond, or a single receptor, how does it respond? I think it makes a lot more sense to work with mice because you can do cell type specific knockouts and throw that into your complicated multi-tissue system. And then, but you're still going to be missing something, probably. And so then you still have to go back to in vivo or take that to human stuff. So I think as long as, you know, the same way we approach every scientific question, this model has some benefits and some caveats, and we're just trying to synthesize everything afterwards.
